goal.en:
The year of 2015 marks the start of a new chapter of sustainable development. Adopted by 193 member states, the UN launched the 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). While sustainable development provides a shared vision for peace and prosperity, the Goals are an urgent call for action by all developed and developing countries in a global partnership.

Global issues such as ending poverty and hunger, improving health and education, reducing inequity, ensuring sustainable consumption and production, preserving oceans and forests and transforming energy to a low-carbon society, cannot be solved through unilateral action and domestic policy alone. This course explores the central interconnection related to international cooperation and sustainable development. It explores topics such as, green growth, social inclusion, energy transition, climate solutions, and public participation in policymaking.

More specifically, how sustainability has been understood, what sets SDGs apart from previous international agreements, how progress can be measured, and how state and non-state actors respond to and implement the SDGs.
